title: Just one in 10 homes built on land released from the Green Belt are ‘affordable’, report finds
text:
Only one in ten homes built on green belt land are affordable, a new report by the Campaign to Protect Rural England (CPRE) has found.

The report argues that far from providing much-needed homes for first-time buyers, development on the Green Belt is instead "squandering" the asset.

While some government ministers argue that building on the Green Belt is one of the solutions to the affordable housing crisis, in the past decade, only 1 in 10 new homes built on land released from the Green Belt in the last decade are considered "affordable".

This trend looks to continue as the research also shows that there are proposals for a further 266,000 homes on undeveloped Green Belt land in advanced local plans, and only a third of these are likely to be classified as ‘affordable’ according to local policies.

Tom Fyans, Deputy Chief Executive of CPRE, the countryside charity, said: "Building homes on the Green Belt is not the answer to the housing crisis.

"Indeed, in terms of the Green Belt, it’s clear that we are reaching a tipping point. The increasing number of new homes proposed on the Green Belt has continued to rise since the report was first undertaken in 2012, despite the fact that these homes are not delivering promised affordable housing. We must not allow our Green Belt to be gobbled up, but instead focus on building affordable homes in which young struggling families can actually live."
